text:
hello everyone in this video I'm going to 
be talking about everything you need to know

about agar agar so that you can successfully 
cook with it so a few months back I put up a

video mango coconut agar agar jelly and it was 
a hit but people have a lot of questions about

the agar agar itself so hopefully this 
video will answer all of those questions

so the first obvious question is what exactly is 
agar-agar and it's a seaweed extract and it can

set liquid into a solid similar to the way gelatin 
does except it's got a very very different texture

so your best bet is to go to an Asian grocery 
store and you can look for it in two forms powder

form which is the one that I use and it comes in 
little packets like this when you open it it's a

fine fine powder just like that and the other form 
is in threads this big long packet here and it's

kind of a weird thing to work with it looks sort 
of like plasticy rope but it will use the exact

same product also if you live close to a Japanese 
grocery store or if your grocery store has a lot

of Japanese products they also have agar agar 
sold under the name can been that's what they

call it so you can look for it under that name as 
well also as a sort of a last resort you can look

for this at health food stores because they sell 
agar agar asks the vegan substitute for gelatin

because if you didn't know gelatin is actually 
made from animal parts and so it's not suitable

for vegetarians so it's sold as sort of the 
health food as well but that tends to be quite

expensive so look first at Asian grocery stores 
then you can look for it at health food stores

if you're using the powder type the ratio that I 
like is one teaspoon for every 320 mils of liquid

or that's a cup and a third okay but that's a 
flexible ratio you can use a little less liquid

and then it'll be firmer don't go to much more 
liquid than that you can push it a little bit

but at some point it does become too soft and 
you won't be able to cut and like maintain its

shape if you're using thick liquid like my mango 
puree you also can use less of it as well if you

are using the thread type I know it can be hard 
to measure cut it into sort of short pieces like

this and then you can measure it and it's going 
to just fly everywhere ever that's okay and then

you pack it into a third of a cup measure that is 
equivalent to a teaspoon of the powder which will

set 320 mils of liquid this is simple yet tricky 
at the same time if you're using the powder type

you want to add it to cold water stir and then 
bring it to a boil never add powdered agar into

hot water because if you do it'll clump up and it 
would be impossible to get out if you're using the

thread type you want to soak it first in water 
for about 15 minutes and that'll help it hydrate

it'll dissolve faster when you go to cook it this 
type will take longer to dissolve so once it's

soaked you want to bring it to a boil and then 
let it simmer for about 5 minutes or so until

it's completely clear you no longer see any small 
pieces of the agar agar anymore the same goes for

the powder make sure you bring it to a full boil 
it'll be quicker but you want to check the liquid

to make sure that there are no little tiny grains 
take a little bit of the liquid into the spoon and

pour it off and if it's not completely dissolved 
you can usually see tiny little specks of the agar

powder still on it that is a big mistake people 
make is they think it's dissolved but it's not

and then it won't set your liquid another question 
I get a lot is can I use gelatin instead and yes

and no but yeah it depends what you're going for 
so the answer is yes of course you can use gelatin

but you have to realize that it's a very different 
end product at the end so it will set your liquid

but it's not going to be the same thing it has 
a very different mouthfeel gelatin is bouncy

and it melts in your mouth but our grogger is firm 
almost a little crunchy and it's sort of crumbles

in your mouth so it's very two very different 
products it's sort of like making an apple cake

and apple pie that's the analogy I like is the 
same flavor sort of the same ingredients but

it's a very different eating experience so that's 
something that you can decide finally I'm going

to leave you with a couple tips for success always 
dissolve your Agha auger in water or some sort of

a clear liquid so you're going to add mango puree 
or coffee or whatever liquid that is cloudy you

won't be able to see if it's completely dissolved 
so dissolve it completely first in water and then

add your flavoring if you're making a layered agar 
agar like my mango and coconut jelly you want to

make sure that when you pour the second layer on 
the liquid is steaming hot because if it's not hot

enough as if sort of lukewarm the layers won't 
stick together very well and it can easily come

apart normally the layers it's they're not fused 
together tightly anyway but it shouldn't come

apart on its own and that is it for today I hope I 
answered most of your questions about auger auger

and if I miss anything please feel free to write 
me Facebook Twitter or Instagram and I will see

you next time bye bye the first question I get is 
what exactly is it so it is isn't the dream means
